title: 104_hr1882
content: The "Federal Surplus Property Reform Act of 1995" allows the Secretary of Defense special authorities for disposing of excess and surplus property. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Years 1990 and 1991 is repealed, along with support for regional equipment centers in Newport township and Cambria county. There is an expansion of the limitation on the use of excess nonlethal supplies for international assistance programs. The limitation on transferring nonlethal excess supplies from the Department of Defense to foreign countries or organizations is expanded under the Foreign Assistance Act and Arms Export Control Act. Transfer can only occur if no other entity requests the supplies or if the President certifies an emergency need to Congress. The Foreign Assistance Act and Arms Export Control Act restrict the transfer of nonlethal excess supplies from the Department of Defense to foreign entities unless no other requests are made or in case of a certified emergency need. The term 'nonlethal excess supplies' refers to Department of Defense property that is surplus and not intended for causing harm or death. Amendments are made to ensure compliance with these regulations. Amendments are made to comply with regulations regarding the transfer of nonlethal excess supplies from the Department of Defense to foreign entities. Amendments are made to limit the use of nonlethal excess supplies from the Department of Defense in foreign assistance, humanitarian assistance, and military sales programs. This includes eliminating the delegation of disposal authority over personal property to the Secretary of Defense. Amendments are made to restrict the disposal authority of nonlethal excess supplies from the Department of Defense in various programs, excluding personal property. This includes changes to the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990. Amendments restrict disposal authority for nonlethal excess supplies from the Department of Defense, excluding personal property. Amendments to various acts including the Department of Energy Science Education Enhancement Act, Small Business Act, and Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 are made to modify disposal authority for surplus property and enhance science education. Repeal of Section 11(i) of the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 and delegation of authority to directors of Federal laboratories for transfer and disposal of scientific and technical surplus property to educational institutions or nonprofit organizations. The Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 was repealed, and authority was delegated to directors of Federal laboratories for transferring surplus scientific and technical property to educational institutions or nonprofit organizations.
